channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Vietnam Prepares for Impact of 20% Tariff as Investors Back Deal
item.description: Vietnam aims to sign more free trade agreements to diversify its export markets as it grapples with global uncertainty posed by the US tariff offensive.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Giang Nguyen, Nguyen Xuan Quynh

item.title: Surging UK Shipping Costs Threaten to Deliver a New Price Shock
item.description: The cost of shipping goods from China to the UK has surged due to ripple effects of the US trade war, threatening to push up consumer prices and complicate the Bank of England’s plan to keep nudging down interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: South Africa’s Low Growth Leaves Citizens Poorer Than Global Average, Investec Says
item.description: South Africa’s anemic economic growth since 2010 has left its population significantly poorer than the global average, according to Investec Wealth & Investment International.
item.dc:creator: Adelaide Changole

media:content.media:description: Fruit for sale at an outdoor market in Pretoria, South Africa.

item.title: Reeves Should Brave Markets and Swap UK Fiscal Rules, Study Says
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves should revamp her fiscal rules to revive productivity, according to a new report that argues the existing design is damaging the investment needed to generate long-term economic growth and tax revenue.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves

item.title: Trump Vows No Tariff Extension, Hardens Threats on Copper, Drugs
item.description: President Donald Trump vowed to push forward with his aggressive tariff regime in the coming days, stressing he would not offer additional extensions on country-specific levies set to now hit in early August while indicating he could announce substantial new rates on imports of copper and pharmaceuticals.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Thai Central Bank Governor Candidate Defends His Independence
item.description: One of two finalists to run the Bank of Thailand defended himself against accusations by a former governor that he wouldn’t be able to make independent decisions because of his ties to a state-run lender.
item.dc:creator: Anuchit Nguyen

item.title: New Zealand Keeps Rates on Hold Amid Inflation, Trade Uncertainty
item.description: New Zealand’s central bank left interest rates unchanged, pausing after six straight cuts as inflation quickens, but said it expects to ease them further if price pressures abate.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

media:content.media:description: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand building in Wellington, New Zealand.

item.title: China’s Producer Deflation Worsens as Weak Demand Persists
item.description: China’s producer prices fell the most in nearly two years, deepening the country’s factory-gate deflation and overshadowing a modest improvement in consumer prices.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Jing Li

item.title: Korea’s Household Loan Surge Puts Rate-Cut Plans Under Pressure
item.description: South Korea’s household lending surged in June at the fastest pace in 10 months, driven by a hot property market in Seoul that’s complicating the central bank’s efforts to support the economy with looser policy.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: Australia ‘Urgently Seeking’ Detail on Trump’s Drug Tariff Threat
item.description: Australia is “urgently seeking” more detail on President Donald Trump’s threat to impose 200% tariffs on pharmaceutical imports to the US, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Jim Chalmers Photographer: Hilary Wardhaugh/Bloomberg

item.title: Taiwan Signals Cautious Optimism After Avoiding US Tariff Letter
item.description: Taiwan indicated it was cautiously optimistic about talks with the US after it avoided getting a letter from the Trump administration notifying trading partners of new tariff rates.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: People riding on motorcycles wait at a traffic stop as the Taipei 101 building stands in the distance in Taipei, Taiwan.

item.title: Trump Pressures South Korea to Pay More for Defense
item.description: President Donald Trump said South Korea should pay more for its own defense, upping pressure on the Asian ally after sending a letter to extend time for negotiations before 25% across-the-board levies are set to kick in for its shipments to the US.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: JUNG Yeon-Je /AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: China Ramps Up Offshore Wind Projects After Slowdown, GEM Says
item.description: China has rebuilt a substantial pipeline of offshore wind projects as the sector recovers from a slowdown that followed the end of national subsidies in 2021, according to Global Energy Monitor.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh

media:content.media:description: Offshore wind accounts for only a fraction of the country’s total wind power capacity.

item.title: Australia Rate Shock Puts RBA’s Radio Silence Under Scrutiny
item.description: In the seven weeks leading up to the Australian central bank interest rate decision Tuesday, its policymakers sat silent as hot wars in the Middle East and trade wars from the US shook global confidence.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Michele Bullock speaks during a press conference in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, July 8, 2025.

item.title: RBA Will Refresh Research Strategy to Support Policy Making
item.description: Australia’s central bank intends to refresh its research strategy to support policymaking, Deputy Governor Andrew Hauser said, a day after the Reserve Bank shocked investors and economists with an unchanged interest-rate decision.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Andrew Hauser Photographer: Lisa Maree Williams/Bloomberg

item.title: A Tomato Fight With Mexico Is Set to Boost US Prices Nearly 10%
item.description: Consumers may soon be paying more for fresh tomatoes as a decades-long deal with Mexico expires in less than a week, absent a last-minute deal or extension.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Peterson

media:content.media:description: A bucket of tomatoes during a harvest at a farm in Limon de Los Ramos, Mexico.

item.title: Trump’s Copper Tariff Threats Are Already Raising Factory Costs
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s plans to place hefty import tariffs on copper have already caused a spike in costs for American factories, with New York futures trading 25% higher than other global benchmarks on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: An employee carries copper at Industrial Metal Supply Co.'s warehouse in San Diego, California, U.S., on Thursday, Jan. 24, 2013. Industrial Metal Supply Co. is an aluminum, steel and sheet metal supplier serving businesses and retail custmers.

item.title: Uruguay Central Bank Surprises With Quarter-Point Rate Cut
item.description: Uruguay’s central bank cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to 9% and signaled it might further lower borrowing costs if inflation converges with the target.
item.dc:creator: Ken Parks

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at the Tristan Narvaja market in Montevideo, Uruguay, on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024. In Latin America's haven for the rich, Uruguayans are about to decide whether to overhaul their social security system in a controversial $23 billion proposal that's overshadowing the upcoming presidential election.

item.title: Wall Street Bank Stocks’ Furious Rally Spurs HSBC Downgrades
item.description: HSBC is turning cautious on three of the biggest US bank stocks following a record rally that’s brought the group within shouting distance of an all-time high.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: A HSBC bank branch in Enfield, UK.

item.title: South Africa Finance Head Cautions Against Rushing New Inflation Goal
item.description: South Africa’s finance minister said work on lowering the inflation target is “progressing well” but cautioned against rushing the decision.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: South Africa's finance minister Enoch Godongwana

item.title: Trump Says Powell Should ‘Resign Immediately’ If He Misled Congress
item.description: President Donald Trump said Jerome Powell should “resign immediately” if allegations from an administration official that the Federal Reserve chair misled lawmakers prove true, while deepening his personal attacks against the head of the central bank over interest rate policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks during a cabinet meeting in the Cabinet Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on July 8, 2025. (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS / AFP) (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: US Consumer Debt Rises at Slower Pace on Drop in Card Balances
item.description: US consumer borrowing increased in May at the slowest pace in three months on a pullback in credit card and other revolving debt outstanding.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

media:content.media:description: A customer uses a smartphone to pay for a purchase in Seattle.

item.title: Brazil’s Lula Hosts Modi in Bid to Turn India Into a Major Trade Partner
item.description: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva wants to deepen trade ties with India, the world’s most populous nation. The question as he hosts Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Brasilia on Tuesday is how to go about it.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, left, and Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister

item.title: Trump Says He’ll Set 50% Copper Tariff, Wait Year on Drug Levies
item.description: President Donald Trump said he planned to implement a 50% duty on copper imports as part of a set of looming sectoral tariffs, while also indicating he could offer pharmaceutical manufacturers at least a year before applying a crippling 200% tariff on their foreign-made products.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: Worker handles copper plates in a copper electrolysis plant at the Zijinshan mine in Longyan, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa to Model Budget Impact of US Proposed 30% Tariff
item.description: South Africa’s National Treasury is worried that the US’s proposed 30% tariff could hit tax revenues and is modeling the impact it may have on the nation’s budget.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: The financial district and port in Cape Town, South Africa, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Enoch Godongwana, South Africa's finance minister, and his National Treasury officials were sent back to the drawing board last month after his revenue and spending plan failed to get buy-in from parties. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei Approval Rating Holds as Argentines Worry More About Jobs
item.description: President Javier Milei’s approval rating and positive image remained well above domestic peers in June even as Argentines became increasingly worried about the job market after unemployment rose earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Gillespie

media:content.media:description: Javier Milei speaks in National Harbor, Maryland, on Feb. 22. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Macron Pushes Starmer to Recognize Palestine on Visit to UK
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron urged the UK to recognize the state of Palestine in an address to the British parliament that emphasized the need for cooperation amid Middle East tensions and uncertainty over US support.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president, left, and Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, during a wreath laying ceremony at the statue of former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill in Parliament Square in London, UK, on Tuesday, July 8, 2025. Macron arrived in the UK on Tuesday morning for the first state visit by a French leader since 2008.

item.title: ECB Mustn’t Rush Further Rate Moves, Vujcic Tells Handelsblatt
item.description: The European Central Bank mustn’t be too concerned about a temporary undershooting of the 2% inflation target and shouldn’t rush further interest-rate moves, Governing Council member Boris Vujcic told Handelsblatt.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Governor of Croatia's central bank Boris Vujcic

item.title: US Immigration Curbs to Hit Economy Hard in 2025, Fed Study Says
item.description: The Trump administration’s curbs on immigration and ramped-up deportations will lower US economic growth by almost a full percentage point this year, according to a study from the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: A man says goodbye to a woman as Federal agents detain him following an immigration court hearing at Jacob K. Javits Federal Building in New York, on June 10. Photographer: Adam Gray/Getty Images

item.title: BOJ Faces Inflation Risks and Has Room for Hikes, Nakaso Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan must be vigilant to upside inflation risks and has room to hike interest rates further, according to former Deputy Governor Hiroshi Nakaso.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Hiroshi Nakaso, chairman of Daiwa Institute of Research Ltd., speaks at the FinCity Global Forum in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. The event is part of a financial promotion project by FinCity.Tokyo, an organization set up to boost the attractiveness of Tokyo as a financial center. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg
